Answer: I would live in a such future (because I love to live). But I would dislike it.Medieval-style feudal society was not something good compared to our democratic capitalist society.Wealth inequalityThe reparation of wealth was disastrous. The whole “middle class” exists since the industrial revolution. Before the vast majority of the population was VERY poor and a few were VERY rich.There is a mathematical tool for studying that: the Gini coefficient. It is used for measuring the inequality of income or wealth.A Gini coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality, where all values are the same (eI would live in a such future (because I love to live). But I would dislike it.Medieval-style feudal society was not something good compared to our democratic capitalist society.Wealth inequalityThe reparation of wealth was disastrous. The whole “middle class” exists since the industrial revolution. Before the vast majority of the population was VERY poor and a few were VERY rich.There is a mathematical tool for studying that: the Gini coefficient. It is used for measuring the inequality of income or wealth.A Gini coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality, where all values are the same (everyone has the same income, or the same wealth). A Gini coefficient of 1 expresses maximal inequality among values (one single individual has all the wealth, or all the income).Of course, Gini 0 and Gini 1 can’t really be reached (these are theoretical values).The medieval income Gini coefficient for Paris was 0.7 (based on data from 1292 to 1313). Today, the Gini coefficient in France is 0.292.[Income Inequality in Paris in the Heyday of the Commercial Revolution, by Nathan Sussman]Poor human rightsSlavery and serfdom were very common.Women rights were very limited.Religious freedom was very limited.

Answer: Everything you mention is available now, and would be no problem if it weren’t for greed and jealousy. In the US we have more empty houses than homeless people. Water, when it isn’t being poisoned by companies that want to save money by just dumping waste, is plentiful. Food is plentiful, to the point where restaurants and a grocery stores throw out tons of food that they couldn’t sell. We could have universal healthcare if we weren’t obsessed with creating the most expensive standing army in the world. The primary objection to giving people housing, food, education, and medical care is “I hadEverything you mention is available now, and would be no problem if it weren’t for greed and jealousy. In the US we have more empty houses than homeless people. Water, when it isn’t being poisoned by companies that want to save money by just dumping waste, is plentiful. Food is plentiful, to the point where restaurants and a grocery stores throw out tons of food that they couldn’t sell. We could have universal healthcare if we weren’t obsessed with creating the most expensive standing army in the world. The primary objection to giving people housing, food, education, and medical care is “I had to pay for mine so everyone else should too”.From what I’ve read, the same is true for every other developed country (minus the military). Greed, and a “I paid so everyone else should have to suffer if they can’t pay” mentality are preventing us from transitioning to a post-scarcity society.

Answer: I know this sounds cold. But that is not how humans work. We don’t do well when we are given everything. The human psyche is like any muscle in the body. It if is not exorcised, and challenged it will atrophy and die. Look at sheep in the field, they are docile, meek and easy to lead to the slaughter. Then look at the sheep in the wild. They have to forage, fight and struggle to stay alive but they are twice as intelligent as a domesticated sheep. Sometimes the best way to help people is by not helping them but by letting them help themselves. I’m not explaining this well, but the bottom lineI know this sounds cold. But that is not how humans work. We don’t do well when we are given everything. The human psyche is like any muscle in the body. It if is not exorcised, and challenged it will atrophy and die. Look at sheep in the field, they are docile, meek and easy to lead to the slaughter. Then look at the sheep in the wild. They have to forage, fight and struggle to stay alive but they are twice as intelligent as a domesticated sheep. Sometimes the best way to help people is by not helping them but by letting them help themselves. I’m not explaining this well, but the bottom line is people as a whole will not improve but they will becomes less functional. Maybe a sociologist can explain it better.
